awd_titl_txt: Dynamics and Consequences of Increasing Ice-wedge Degradation
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will quantify the nature and extent of ice-wedge degradation, evaluate the feedbacks controlling the dynamics of degradation and stabilization, and assess the consequences of the degradation to arctic ecosystems. Massive ice in the form of ice wedges occupies 10?70% of near- surface permafrost and fundamentally influences the dynamics and vulnerability of arctic ecosystems to climate change. Arctic permafrost has been considered stable because ground temperatures remain low, but recent observations in northern Alaska of an abrupt increase in degradation of ice-wedges, indicate that even permafrost in the Arctic is susceptible to degradation from climate change because of the massive ice that has formed just below the active layer. High-resolution satellite images of Alaska and Russia reveal that ice-wedge degradation is more extensive in the Arctic than in the subarctic because of this near-surface ice. The dynamics of ice-wedge degradation has been shown to be affected by the positive feedback of impounded surface water and negative feedbacks from rapid vegetation and peat accumulation that are able to stabilize degrading ice wedges, yet there has been no quantification of the physical mechanisms controlling the processes. This degradation of ice wedges greatly affects arctic ecosystems by altering surface topography, modifying drainage networks, enhancing peat accumulation and methane production under anaerobic conditions, and radically shifting vegetation composition, but these consequences are poorly understood. Given that ice-wedge degradation directly or indirectly affects most arctic terrain it is critical to quantify the dynamics and consequences of ice-wedge degradation.

This project addresses these uncertainties through a comprehensive assessment of the nature and extent of ice-wedge degradation, the feedbacks controlling ice-wedge dynamics, and the consequences of degradation on ecosystem patterns and processes. The research brings together an interdisciplinary team with expertise in permafrost and soil, biogeochemisty and trace gas emissions, vegetation, and remote sensing to address hypotheses through field surveys, remote sensing, and modeling. The extent and rate of ice-wedge degradation across landscapes and climates will be assessed by comparing the ice-wedge volume by terrain units, describing stages of degradation and stabilization; quantifying degradation across the circumarctic; developing image processing algorithms for mapping thermokarst; and quantifying degradation rates through aerial photo analysis. How the dynamics of ice- wedge degradation and stabilization are controlled by positive and negative feedbacks will be assessed by identifying structural properties of surface soils that protect ice wedges; quantifying differences in net radiation and soil heat flux among degradation stages; and identifying thresholds for thermokarst through numerical modeling. The consequences of ice-wedge degradation will be documented by quantifying micro-topographic changes caused by ice-wedge degradation; changes in surface water storage and drainage patterns; soil-organic carbon stocks through degradation sequence; differences in methane emissions among degradation stages; and quantifying shifts in vegetation composition through degradation sequence. 

The research is essential for understanding of the effects of climate changes on permafrost and arctic ecosystems because ice wedges are especially sensitive component of terrestrial arctic ecosystems. Knowledge of the nature and extent of ice wedges will improve land management, impact assessment, and facility design in ice-rich permafrost terrain. Information on the dynamics and feedbacks involved in ice-wedge degradation is needed to minimize effects of disturbance and to improve global climate change models that currently lack critical feedbacks. Documentation of the consequences of degradation is needed to better assess the role of fragmenting drainage networks in assessments of circumarctic hydrology, help resolve whether arctic soils will gain or lose carbon in the future, contribute information for assessing methane emissions across dynamically changing ecosystems, and provide data on the rates of vegetation change which can affect satellite measurement of vegetation productivity during assessments of vegetation greening in the Arctic.

por.por_cntn:
Ice wedges are the main type of the massive ground ice in the permafrost region. Permafrost is any soil or rock that remains below 32°F throughout the year. To be considered permafrost, it must remain frozen for two consecutive years or more. Permafrost is found in cold climates where the mean annual temperature is below freezing.

In many Arctic regions of North America and Eurasia, including northern Alaska, ice-wedge polygons cover practically the entire land surface. Massive ice in the form of ice wedges occupies 10–70% of near-surface permafrost, and it fundamentally influences the dynamics and vulnerability of Arctic ecosystems to climate change. For a long time, ice wedges have been considered stable and some of them have survived for many thousands of years.

In our field work in the Arctic, we noticed an exploding number of melting ice wedges since the early 1990s. High-resolution satellite images of Alaska and Russia reveal that ice-wedge degradation is more extensive in the Arctic than in the Subarctic because ice wedges in the Arctic tend to be located very close to the surface. Some scientists have been concerned that thawing ice wedges in the Arctic is the first sign of a large-scale permafrost degradation in the circumpolar north.

In this research project, funded by the NSF Office of Polar Programs, we studied ice-wedge degradation at four sites in the Arctic where permafrost is continuous and at two sites in the discontinuous permafrost zone. Most degradation of ice wedges found at studied sites in the Arctic has been caused by a sudden increase in summer temperatures that occurred in 1989 and 1998. In the discontinuous permafrost zone, this degradation was caused mainly by human impacts on soil surface.   

Our studies showed that after initial stages of ice-wedge degradation, some processes begin to resist further degradation of ice wedges (we call these negative feedbacks). These effects are associated with development of aquatic vegetation in thermokarst ponds and accumulation of soil eroded from the sides of ice-wedge troughs in the bottom of ponds. These negative feedbacks lead to a decrease in the active-layer thickness above degrading ice wedges. As a result, a layer of permanently frozen soil (the intermediate layer) forms on top of ice wedges and protects them from further degradation.

We identified and described the main stages of ice-wedge degradation and stabilization, and developed a comprehensive model of this process. We showed that in many cases ice-wedge degradation is reversible, and, finally, this reversal makes ice wedges more stable than before degradation occurred. We developed a system for evaluating the risk of ice-wedge degradation based on the thickness of protective soil layers above ice wedges.

During this study, we had a rare opportunity to study river erosion of ice-rich permafrost that contained ice wedges that were 15 to more than 50 thousand years old and extended vertically over 35 meters. The rate of riverbank erosion at this study site (Itkillik River, northern Alaska) reached almost 20 m/year. We identified and described three main stages of the riverbank degradation and stabilization.

Scientists from the USA, Russia, Canada, and Germany collaborated in this research. Undergraduate and graduate students participated in this research, gaining knowledge in the science of permafrost, arctic biology, and hydrology. We have shared our findings with scientific community and Federal and State agencies through numerous publications, presentations, seminars, and reports. It you would like to review our project data, visit this address and click "data sets":

https://www.aoncadis.org/project/ice-wedge_degradation.html
